choices.text: It is distributed free of cost under NLEP
useful Not for anesthesia of foot for causes other than leprosy
It is made up of nylon material
Provided to only those who have completed MDT

questions.text: True about the following is :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above image shows Microcellulose Rubber footwear.

  • Available free of cost under NLEP
  • Used for the patient who have high risk of developing ulcer due to anesthesia on foot
  • Used for the patient with the scars of old ulcers
  • Made up of plastozole and microcellular rubber
  • Patient who is on MDT / or completed are eligible under NLEP
Source : national leprosy eradication programme, NHM.

questions.text: Which of the following sequence is true for selection of nerve for biopsy?
questions.solution:
• A clinically involved nerve must be selected for the biopsy. The ideal nerve is the sural nerve,although a sensory branch of the radial cutaneous nerve can be biopsied. In more than 90% ofpatients, the sural nerve is largely a sensory nerve; in the remaining 10% of patients, it containsonly a few motor fibers (12).
  • The sural nerve is commonly involved in leprosy and is easily accessible for surgery. Following the biopsy, a formalin-fixed nerve segment is dissected in 2-4 pieces that are arranged transversely and longitudinally in a paraffin block to cut sections of 3-4mm thickness.

Reference: International textbook of leprosy, section 9

choices.text: There is nerve fiber impairment without type 1 or 2 lepra reaction
There is nerve fiber impairment without leprosy
There is nerve fiber impairment without neuritis
There is nerve fiber impairment without paresthesia or numbness

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about silent neuropathy?
questions.solution:
• Silent neuropathy is defined as sensory or motor impairment in leprosy without the skin signs of a Type 1 or Type 2 reaction, without evident nerve tenderness, and without spontaneous complaints of nerve pain (burning or shooting pain), paraesthesia, or numbness.
  • The possible mechanisms by which nerves are damaged, leading to silent neuropathy, are Schwann cell pathology, nerve fibrosis, a CMI reaction, and an intraneural Type 2 reaction
Reference: International textbook of leprosy, section 9

choices.text: A 22-year-old female who reports using a tanning bed three times per week.
A 55-year-old male with dark skin that reports always wearing sunscreen while outdoors.
A 35-year-old female with light-colored skin and eyes that reports frequent sunburns as a child.
A 29-year-old who reports a family history of melanoma.

questions.text: Which among the following patients below who are not at a HIGH risk for developing skin cancer?
questions.solution:
• Risk factors for skin cancer include too much exposure to the sun, usage of tanning beds, family history, light-coloured skin and eyes, exposure to toxic chemicals on the skin, and frequent sunburns as a child.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology , 9th edition, Chapter 130

questions.text: Match the agent causing chemical leucoderma
questions.solution:
• P- tertiary butyl phenol - Bindi
  • Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone - rubber
  • Para phenyl diamine - hair dye

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology , 9th edition, Chapter 130

questions.text: Which of the following STI is associated with the following?
questions.solution:
• The image shows ophthalmia neaonatorum.
  • Occurs when mother is infected with gonorrhea
  • Presents one week after birth
  • Painful red eye with purulent discharge

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 31

choices.text: Lightening of color of nipples and areola

questions.text: Which of the following physiological skin changes are not seen during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Physiological changes of skin during pregnancy can be listed as follows:

  • Darkening of areola, nipples genitalia
  • Linea nigra
  • Striae distensae
  • Post partum telogen effluvium
  • Spider nevi
  • Palmar erythema
  • Increased in sebaceous and eccrine gland activity
  • Decrease Apocrine gland activity
  • Hirsutism ( rarely)
  • Pyogenic granuloma
  • Nail changes

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 115

questions.text: A 35 year old male develops purple red ova; macule after taking metronidazole. History of similar lesion at the same site six month back. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Fixed pigmented erythema (FPE), also known as a fixed drug eruption, occurs 24 hours to a few days after administration of the offending medication.
  • The classic form is characterized by a single or multiple round to oval-shaped, red to brown macules. These lesions have the potential to evolve into plaques with vesicles or blistering.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 113

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the histopathological changes of Lichen planus?
questions.solution:
• Small subepidermal clefts (Max-Joseph spaces) may be seen at the base or sides of the rete which show short angulated hyperplasia resulting in the typical 'sawtooth' pattern of the rete.
  • Wedge-shaped hypergranulosis, compact orthokeratosis, irregular rete ridges and a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate in the widened papillary dermis.
  • Colloid (Civatte) bodies that represent anucleated remnants of apoptotic basal keratinocytes may be seen in the basal layer as well in the uppermost papillary dermis, where they may be present as single units or in small clumps.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 45

questions.text: Which of the following microorganism is a predominant flora of the skin?
questions.solution:
• The normal human skin is colonized by huge numbers of bacteria that live harmlessly as commensals on its surface and within its follicles. The resident bacteria together with fungal flora are known as skin microbiome. At times overgrowth of some of the resident organism may cause minor skin disease .
  • Of the coagulase negative staph, stap epidermidis is the major bacteria. However staph hemolyticus, s saprophyticus and s warneri are important flora.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 26

questions.text: The anti retroviral drug commonly implicated to cause DRESS [ drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms is :
questions.solution:
• Nevirapine is NNRTI - non nucleoside reverse transcriptse inhibitors.It is known to cause DRESS.
  • Zidovudine : myopathy , lactic acidosis
  • Abacavir : HLA B5701 hypersensitivity
  • Doultegravir : pruritus and rash

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 26

questions.text: the image shows the upper lip edema , and patient also had lower motor neuron type facial palsy. Which one of the finding is a part of melkerson Rosenthal syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Earliest cutaneous manifestation is sudden , diffuse nodular swelling involving the upper lip, lower lip and one or both the cheeks in decreasing order of frequency.
  • A fissured tongue or scrotal is seen in 20 to 40 percent cases.
  • Facial palsy of lower motor neuron type may be seen in 30% cases.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 110

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic factor for vitiligo?
questions.solution:
• Poor prognostic factors of Vitiligo:
  • history of progression, family history of vitiligo, widespread disease, non-segmental vitiligo, acrofacial vitiligo, mucosal involvement and leukotrichia.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 88

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for impetigo herpetiformis?
questions.solution:
• Impetigo herpetiformis = pustular psoriasis in pregnancy.
  • Methotrexate , isotretinoin and acitretin are contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • Systemic steroids is the drug of choice.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 88

questions.text: Which of the following tinea capitis will show florescene on woods lamp?
questions.solution:
• Woods lamp is an important bed side test for tinea capitis.
  • Species showing floroscene:
  • Microsporum species - ectothrix type
  • Trichophyton schonlonie - favus

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter31

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is very common among elderly patients and especially likely if itching is primarily on the lower extremities?
questions.solution:
• Xerotic eczema is very common among elderly patients. It is especially likely if itching is primarily on the lower extremities.
  • Choices B and D are possibilities, but itching is usually more widespread. Choice A usually involves the extensor aspects of the elbows, knees, sacrum, buttocks, and occiput.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter39

questions.text: Most common organism causing the below condition is :
questions.solution:
• The image shows tinea nigra
  • Causative orgasnism : exophilia wernecki
  • Mostly asymptomatic
  • Affects skin of palms
  • Presents as macular, deeply pigmented non scaly patches.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter32

choices.text: It is commonly seen at birth
It is caused due to staphylococcal exfoliative toxin
Presents with erosions and raw areas over the body

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true about staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Also known as ritters syndrome
  • Caused staph phage group 2 strains 55 and 71
  • By exfoliative/ epidermolytic toxin A and B
  • Rare at birth
  • Source of infection : umbilicus, breast, site of herniorapphy / circumcision
  • Begins with macular erythema which progresses to red raw areas and erosion
  • Presence of skin tenderness
  • Treatment is IV antibiotics and fluid management

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter116

questions.text: WHICH OF the following cells are not present in epidermis?
questions.solution:
• Mast cells are present in dermis

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter2

questions.text: Bacterial vaginosis is a vaginal infection that occurs when the balance of bacteria in the vagina is altered. Which of the following is a common vaginal symptom of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Vaginal discharge may be gray or white, thin, and profuse, and the discharge usually has a fishy odor.
  • It is preferred to give pregnant patients metronidazole via vaginal pessary or less commonly gel, which is the safest route of administration.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter2

questions.text: A patient presents with you with the following. Which of the following lasers will you recommend him?
questions.solution:
• Fractional CO2 laser: resurfacing for acne scar/ varicella scar/ rejuvenation
  • Qswitched Nd YAG : pigmented skin lesion
  • Excimer laser: similar to phototherapy
  • Pulse dye laser: vascular lesion

Reference: Sawant's textbook of dermatosurgery and cosmetology 3rd edition

questions.text: Aspiration of subcutaneous fat using canula with vaccum pump is called :
questions.solution:
• Liposuction is the surgical removal of subcutaneous fat by means of suction-assisted aspiration cannulae introduced through small skin incisions.
  • Synonyms include liposuction surgery, suction-assisted lipectomy, suction lipoplasty, fat suction, blunt suction lipectomy, and liposculpture.

Reference: Sawant's textbook of dermatosurgery and cosmetology 3rd edition

questions.text: Glogau classification is used for :
questions.solution: Reference: Sawant's textbook of dermatosurgery and cosmetology 3rd edition

choices.text: VVC occurring more than 4 times in a year
VVC occurring more than 6 times in a year
VVC occurring more than 5 times in a year
VVC occurring more than 3 times in a year

questions.text: True about recurrent vulvovaginal candidiasis (VVC)is:
questions.solution:
• Recurrent VVC, usually defined as three or more episodes
  • of symptomatic VVC in <1 year, affects <5% of women but
  • carries a substantial economic burden
  • Recurrent VVC
  • can be either idiopathic or secondary (related to frequent
  • antibiotic use, diabetes, or other underlying host factors)
  • Treatment
  • Most episodes of recurrent VVC caused by C. albicans
  • respond well to short-duration oral or topical azole therapy.
  • However, to maintain clinical and mycologic control, a longer duration of initial therapy (e.g., 7-14 days of topical therapy or a 100-mg, 150-mg, or 200-mg oral dose of fluconazole every third day for a total of 3 doses [days 1, 4, and 7])is recommended, to attempt mycologic remission, before initiating a maintenance antifungal regimen.
  • Oral fluconazole (i.e., a 100-mg, 150-mg, or 200-mg dose)
  • weekly for 6 months is the indicated maintenance regimen.

Reference:CDC guidelines, sexually transmitted infection, 2021

choices.text: Acyclovir / valacyclovir is the drug of choice
Acyclovir 5% cream is used in children
Excision is the treatment of choice

questions.text: which of the following is true about the given image?
questions.solution:
• The molluscum virus infection is localized to the epidermal layers where it induces a typical, complex hyperproliferative lesion with an abundance of virus particles but a conspicuous, absence of immune response.
  • By not crossing the basement membrane the virus evades immune surveillance. The lesions are often self-limiting as most of them resolve without treatment, with the average length of infection lasting between 6 and 18 months
  • Molluscum contagiosum (MC) is a self-limiting skin infection caused by poxvirus, commonly seen in children with a prevalence of 8-12%. Infection follows contact with infected persons or contaminated objects, and the diagnosis is clinical
  • Antivirals are not indicated in the treatment

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 25

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of SCORTEN?
questions.solution:
Box 119.6 T he seven parameters used to calculate

SCORTE N (SCORe of Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis)

  • Age greater than 40 years
  • Presence of malignancy
  • Heart rate >120 beats/min
  • Epidermal detachment >10% of BSA at admission
  • Serum urea >10 mmol/L
  • Serum glucose >14 mmol/L
  • Bicarbonate level <20 mmol/L

Reference:rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition 119.19

questions.text: A patient presents to you with non healing ulcer over the heal of left foot. On further examination patient has hypoethesia over the bilateral feet. The patient says that few years back he was diagnosed as leprosy by examining skin of ear. Which investigation the patient was subjected to ?
questions.solution:
• Slit-skin smears
  • The lesion is cleaned with ether or alcohol, and the pinna skin is gripped firmly between thumb and forefinger to render it blood free.
  • An incision 5 mm long and 3 mm deep is made with a small-bladed scalpel (size 15 Bard Parker blade); the blade is turned at right angles to the cut, and without relaxing finger pressure, the wound is scraped several times in one direction.
  • Fluid and pulp from the dermis, collected on one side of the blade, are gently smeared on to a glass slide. A bloody smear is useless. The smear is then fixed over a flame and stained.

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, chapter 28.14

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a three-day history of a slightly pruritic rash on her chest. She had an upper respiratory tract infection a few days before the rash appeared. On examination, the rash is salmon-colored, oval, and has a surrounding ring of scale. It has a characteristic Christmas tree distribution.What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Pityriasis rosea (PR) is a self-limited acute exanthem with a presumed viral etiology. It typically presents with a single herald patch or primary plaque on the chest, back, or neck. The Christmas tree rash then develops over the next 1 - 2 weeks. < /li>
  • PR is typically a self-limited condition that resolves within 6-12 weeks. Conservative supportive measures, including emollients, oral antihistamines, and the avoidance of irritants, are sufficient for alleviating symptoms in most patients.
  • Medium - potency topical corticosteroids may also be used to control PR - associated pruritis. < /li>

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition,chapter 35

questions.text: Which sign is positive in such patients?
questions.solution:
• All lesions of psoriasis exhibit Auspitz sign, or pinpoint bleeding when the surface of a psoriatic lesion is removed.
  • This reflects elongated vessels in the dermal papillae, together with thinning of the epidermis.
  • A diagnosis of guttate psoriasis can usually be made on history and clinical grounds alone. Guttate psoriasis is most common in young people.
  • The disease is self-limited in most people
  • Antenna sign is seen in keratosis pilaris.
  • Asboe-Hansen sign is seen in patients with pemphigus and bullous pemphigoid. Barnett's sign is ridging and tightening of the skin when the neck is hyperextended.

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 35

choices.text: Burrow is present in stratum corneum
Burrow appears yellow on woods lamp
Burrows are located in the distribution -hebra circle
Burrow is a classical sign of scabies

questions.text: True about the burrow of scabies is all except:
questions.solution:
• Burrow is present in stratum corneum
  • Demonstration of a burrow in scabies by applying a fluorescent substance like tetracycline paste- appear yellow or fluorescein dye. Doesn't directly show florescene
  • Burrows are located in the distribution - hebra circle
  • Burrow is a classical sign of scabies

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 33

choices.text: It is a type of scarring alopecia
Exclamation mark hair is a characteristic finding
Hair transplant is the treatment of choice
The alopecia shown in the image is trichotillomania

questions.text: All of the following statements are false for the given image except:
questions.solution:
• It is a type of non-scarring alopecia
  • Exclamation mark hair: proximal part of hair is constricted while there is distal thickening

  • Treatment modality: intralesional steroids are treatment of choice. With wide are involvement systemic immunosuppressive agents or systemic steroids are used.
  • Typically, the surface of AA patches is smooth and normal skin color without any skin alterations like scaling and follicular changes.
  • Rarely, it can be peachy or red.Characteristic ′exclamatory mark hairs′ are seen either within or at the border of the patches.
  • These are fractured and short hairs with proximal tapering, close to scalp and distal thickening and widening.
  • The presence of exclamatory hairs at the border and the hair pull test with 6 or more hairs from the periphery suggests that the patch may be active and progressive.

Reference:Rooks text book of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 89

questions.text: The partner treatment is not necessary when treating with which syndromic management kit?
questions.solution:
• The following conditions do not require partner treatments:
  • Herpes genitalis
  • Candidiasis
  • Bacterial vaginosi s
  • Herpes genitalis is treated by red kit

Reference:CDC guidelines, sexually transmitted infection, 2021

questions.text: ERYTHEMA AND EDEMA IS SEEN AFTER STROKING THE SKIN. THIS SIGN is seen in the following :
questions.solution:
• Darier's Sign :The skin characteristically urticates within minutes of gentle rubbing in children causing localized pruritus, redness and wealing, which subside within an hour.
  • Darier's sign is not always demonstrable, especially in the adultform of urticaria pigmentosa with a long history of the disorder or a child with resolving lesions, it is not 100% specific for mastocytosis,
  • since it has been described on rare occasions in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukaemia of neonates

Reference:rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition chapter 42

choices.text: 2.5% benzoyl peroxide is used for its treatment
Resorcinol sulfur combination is one of the treatment modality
Generally seen with the consumption of anabolic steroids

questions.text: Following is true about truncal acne except :
questions.solution:
• 5-10% benzoyl peroxide is used for the treatment of truncal acne.
  • 5/3.5 % benzoyl peroxide is used for the treatment of facial acne
  • It is associated with anabolic steroids, systemic steroid, anti tb drugs and some anti epileptic drugs.

Reference:Rooks text book of Dermatology , Ninth edition, chapter 90

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, HIV positive presents with a six-month history of productive cough, night sweats, and weight loss presents with the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• IN TB, On examination, unilateral neck swelling with, freely mobile, discrete, non-tender lymph nodes is a common finding.
  • As time passes, swelling becomes firm, attached to surrounding tissues, rubbery and matted.
  • Ulceration, sinus draining (4% to 11%) caseous material with fluctuant swelling, fistula formation arise as the disease progresses.
  • Tuberculosis is caused by a number of species in the mycobacterium tuberculosis complex, including mycobacterium bovis, mycobacterium africanum, mycobacterium caprae, and mycobacterium orygis.

Reference: IADVL's textbook of dermatology 4th Edition, chapter 14

choices.text: No florescene as there is no deposition of antibodies
linear C3 and IgG along the dermal-epidermal junction
granular C3 and IgG along the dermal-epidermal junction
linear C3 and IgA along the dermal-epidermal junction

questions.text: An 80 year old male patient presents to the ER with fluid filled lesion over the whole body. The bullae are tense. Skin biopsy shows subepidermal split. Which of the following would be seen on direct immunoflorescene?
questions.solution:
• Bullous pemphigoid is the most common autoimmune blistering disorder.
  • The histopathology of bullous pemphigoid reveals a subepidermal split with many eosinophils in the blister cavity.
  • The direct immunofluorescence pattern will reveal linear C3 and IgG along the dermal-epidermal junction.
  • Indirect immunofluorescence studies including salt-split skin staining on the roof of the blister (epidermal side) and ELISA testing may also be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
  • The treatment of choice is prednisolone

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition chapter 50

questions.text: 7-year-old girl presents to your clinic with a multi-day history of fever, sore throat, and dusky vesicles, pustules, and erosions on the hands, feet, and buttocks. Oral examination reveals multiple erosions with surrounding erythema. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
• Hand-foot-and mouth disease caused by coxackievirus.

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology ninth edition chapter 117

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents to the doctor with a diagnosis of trichotillomania from another doctor. On assessment today, the patient expresses doubts about the diagnosis as she has not been pulling out the hair, but there are still bald patches noted. What additional test will most likely lead to the most accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• No laboratory or additional tests are generally needed for the diagnosis of trichotillomania; in most cases, clinical diagnosis is sufficient.
  • If the history and physical presentation become complicated and unclear and other differential diagnoses like alopecia areata remain possible, using trichography may be the most helpful test to determine if trichotillomania is the accurate diagnosis in these ambiguous cases.

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter85

questions.text: Bullous pemphigoid is a chronic autoimmune skin disorder that occurs more often in patients > 60 years of age. Which of the following is the most common initial symptom?
questions.solution:
• This is the first symptom of bullous pemphigoid. Bullae (choice A) may not develop for several years after the initial symptom of pruritis.
  • Choice B: Fever is rare.
  • Choice D: This symptom may precede an outbreak of the bullae.

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition chapter 50

choices.text: Bullae are flaccid and of various sizes
Lesions shear off skin, leaving painful erosions

questions.text: If a patient presents with blisters, it is most appropriate to differentiate bullous pemphigoid from pemphigus vulgaris,. Differentiation is usually possible using clinical criteria. Of the following clinical observation, which best differentiates bullous pemphigoid from pemphigus vulgaris?
questions.solution:
• Nikolsky sign is negative. This is a clinical indication that the patient most likely has bullous pemphigoid. Choices A, B, and C: These are all clinical manifestations of pemphigus vulgaris.

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition chapter 50

questions.text: A 22 year old women developed small itchy weals immediately after walking in the sun. the most likely diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
• Solar urticaria is a chronic acquired photosensitivity disorder. It consists of recurrent episodes of urticaria rash developed on areas of the skin that are exposed to sunlight.
  • The diagnosis of solar urticaria is confirmed by photo-testing using UVA, UVB, and visible light sources. It is performed to determine the spectrum of action and the triggering wavelengths.
  • Photo testing is performed to determine the minimal urticarial dose. This is the minimal dose inducing an urticarial reaction.
  • Determining the spectrum of action is also important for subsequent management so that patients take precautions to avoid the triggering wavelengths.

Reference:rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition chapter 42

questions.text: Which of the following type of nevus is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• Nevus of Ota corresponds to dermal hypermelanocytosis of the periorbital region.
  • In the papillary and upper reticular dermis, dendritic melanocytes are present and surrounded by fibrous sheaths (which are not present in another dermal melanocytosis, such as blue nevus or congenital dermal melanocytosis).
  • It is caused by the entrapment of melanocytes in the upper third of the dermis.

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition chapter 138

questions.text: A patient of psoriasis was referred to psychiatrist for maniac episode. She was started on a drug which led to the exacerbation of lesions. Identify the drug.
questions.solution: Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 35

choices.text: it takes 25 times more UV to develop erythema
25% of total UV is blocked

questions.text: The use of a sunscreen with SPF 25 means:
questions.solution:
• SPF = minimal erythema dose of unprotected skin / minimal erythema dose of protected skin
  • Hence spf 25 means it takes 25 times more UV to develop erythem

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 9

choices.text: This is a type of deep fungal infection
Woods lamp will show copper orange florescene
Stretching the lesions reveals the presence of a fine overlying scale
Clobetasol is the treatment of choice

questions.text: A 20 -year-old male presents to the clinic with the following:. Examination reveals multiple hypopigmented macules and patches on his chest and arm. Some lesions are discreet, whereas others appear confluent. Which of the following is an appropriate statement for this patient?
questions.solution:
• It is a superficial fungal infection P versicolor
  • Sratch sign is +: Stretching the lesions reveals the presence of a fine overlying scale
  • Ketoconazole is the treatment of choice
  • Causative agent is malessezia furfur

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9 th edition chapter 32

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with no significant past medical history present with the following. . Biopsy reveals infiltration of histiocytes between the dermal collagen fibers, with scant mucin. , what is the best treatment option for the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • High potency topical corticosteroids and intralesional corticosteroid injections are the mainstays of therapy for granuloma annulare.
  • Although evidence is limited, some experts believe hydroxychloroquine should be first-line for generalized but not localized granuloma annulare.
  • Lesions of granuloma annulare tend to recur even after successful treatment.
  • The disease is usually self-limiting but the disease may take over a year to spontaneous resolve.

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9 th edition chapter 147

choices.text: Primary acantholysis is caused by damage to epidermal cells
The damage to keratinocyte is followed by damage to desmosomes
Darrier disease and Hailey Hailey disease are examples of primary acantholysis
Herpes simplex is the example of primary acantholysis

questions.text: True about primary acantholysis:
questions.solution:
• Primary acantholysis: Dissociation and disintegration of desmosomes leads to the separation of keratinocytes; either due to direct injury to desmosomes or due to hereditar defects in their construction.
  • Thus, in these diseases, acantholysis is the primary event leading to the formation of intra-epidermal cavities and hence the manifestations of the disease.
  • Primary acantholysis is of prime pathogenetic relevance in diseases of the pemphigus group, darrier and Hailey hailey disease.

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9 th edition chapter 3.32

questions.text: A 40 year old female had flaccid bullae over the skin and oral erosion. Histopathology shows intra epidermal blisters. What is clinical sign that should be elicited in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Nikolsky's sign is pathognomic for pemphigus, toxic epidermal necrolysis, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). This sign basically differentiates intraepidermal blisters from subepidermal blisters.
  • It is elicited by applying tangential/lateral pressure by a thumb or a finger in the perilesional skin, affected skin, or normal skin, which results in a force that dislodges upper layers of epidermis from lower layers

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 50

choices.text: It is made up of simple squamous epithelium
Most of the skin have 5 layers of epidermis

questions.text: Which of the following is true:
questions.solution:
• Epidermis is a vascular, while dermis is vascular
  • Epidermis originates from ectoderm
  • It is made up of stratified squamous epithelium
  • Most of the skin has 4 layers, except palm and soles.

Reference:Rooks textbookofdermatology9thedition chapter 3

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the casualty due to a sudden-onset rash. She reports that she was prescribed amoxicillin for streptococcal pharyngitis. Currently, she complains of a sore throat and fatigue. The patient has no past medical history and takes no regular medications. On examination, she has an erythematous oropharynx without exudates, and a diffuse maculopapular rash. No mucosa is involved. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Patient has taken a penicillin antibiotic, such as amoxicillin, can develop a morbilliform drug eruption. This patient is most likely having an adverse drug reaction (ADR).
  • The most common drugs causing cutaneous ADRs are penicillin derivatives, allopurinol, sulfonamides, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs).
  • Mucous membrane involvement is rare. It would indicate a severe cutaneous ADR such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, or a drug hypersensitivity reaction

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology 9th edition 47.6
